case_name: the appellant company v. the respondent

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 162 of 1952 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 162 of 1952. Appeal from the Judgment and Order dated the 7th day of June, 1951, of the High Court of Judicature at Calcutta in Income-tax Reference No. 60 of 1950 arising out of the Order dated the 22nd day of November, 1949, of the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal in I.T.A. Nos. 1026 and 1027 of 1948-49 C. Chatterjee for the appellant. Porus A. Mehta for the respondent. 1954. November, 11.

facts.text: Appeal from High Court judgment and order dated 7th June 1951 in Income-tax Reference No. 60 of 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the Judgment and Order dated the 7th day of June, 1951, of the High Court of Judicature at Calcutta in Income-tax Reference No. 60 of 1950 arising out of the Order dated the 22nd day of November, 1949, of the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal in I.T.A. Nos. 1026 and 1027 of 1948-49

facts.text: High Court reference arose from Income-tax Appellate Tribunal order dated 22nd November 1949 in I.T.A. Nos. 1026 and 1027 of 1948-49.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the Order dated the 22nd day of November, 1949, of the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal in I.T.A. Nos. 1026 and 1027 of 1948-49 C. Chatterjee for the appellant. Porus A. Mehta for the respondent. 1954. November, 11. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by, BHAGWATI J.-This appeal from the judgment And order of the High Court of Judicature at Calcutta with leave under section 66-A  2  of the Indian Income-tax Act raises an interesting question as to the line of demarcation between capital expenditure and revenue expenditure.

facts.text: Appellant company acquired lease of limestone quarries (Komorrah) from Government of Assam on 14th November 1938 for 20 years commencing 1st November 1938 ending 31st October 1958, renewable for further 20 years.

anchor.surface_text: On the 14th November, 1938, the appellant companypany acquired from the Government of Assam a lease of certain limestone quarries, known as the Komorrah quarries situated in the Khasi and Jaintia Hills District for the purpose of carrying on the manufacture of cement. The lease was for 20 years companymencing on the 1st November, 1938, and ending on the 31st October, 1958, with a clause for renewal for a further term of 20 years.

facts.text: Lease rent: half-yearly Rs. 3,000 for first two years, thereafter Rs. 6,000 half-yearly, plus royalties.

anchor.surface_text: The rent reserved was a half-yearly rent certain of Rs. 3,000 for the first two years and thereafter a half-yearly rent certain of Rs. 6,000 with the provision for payment of further royalties in certain events.

facts.text: Clause 4 of lease: annual protection fee Rs. 5,000 payable during whole lease from 15th November 1938 for protection in Durgasil area.

anchor.surface_text: Under clause 4 the protection was in respect of another group of quarries called the Durgasil area, the lessor undertaking number to grant any lease, permit or prospecting licence regarding the limestone to any other party therein without a companydition that numberlimestone should be used for the manufacture of cement in companysideration of a sum of Rs. 5,000 payable annually during the whole period of the lease.

facts.text: Clause 5 of lease: further protection fee Rs. 35,000 annually for 5 years from 15th November 1940 for whole Khasi and Jaintia Hills District.

anchor.surface_text: Under clause 5 a further protection was given in respect of the whole of the Khasi and Jaintia Hills District, a similar undertaking being given by the lessor in companysideration of a sum of Rs. 35,000 payable annually but only for 5 years from the 15th November, 1940.

facts.text: Company paid Rs. 40,000 to lessor in accounting years 1944-45 and 1945-46 under clauses 4 and 5.

anchor.surface_text: In the accounting years 1944-45 and 1945-46 the companypany paid its lessor sums of Rs. 40,000 in accordance with these two companyenants and claimed to deduct the sums in the companyputation of its business profits under the provisions of section 10 2   xv  of the Income-tax Act in the assessments for the assessment years 1945-46 and 1946-47.

facts.text: Company claimed deduction of Rs. 40,000 under section 10(2)(xv) for assessments 1945-46 and 1946-47.

anchor.surface_text: the companypany paid its lessor sums of Rs. 40,000 in accordance with these two companyenants and claimed to deduct the sums in the companyputation of its business profits under the provisions of section 10 2   xv  of the Income-tax Act in the assessments for the assessment years 1945-46 and 1946-47.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer rejected the claim.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer, the Appellate Assistant Commissioner and the Appellate Tribunal rejected the companytention of the companypany

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner rejected the claim.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer, the Appellate Assistant Commissioner and the Appellate Tribunal rejected the companytention of the companypany

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal rejected the claim and referred question to High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer, the Appellate Assistant Commissioner and the Appellate Tribunal rejected the companytention of the companypany and the following question, as ultimately reframed, was at the instance of the companypany referred by the Tribunal to the High Court for its decision - Whether, in the circumstances of the case, the two sums of Rs. 5,000 and Rs. 35,000 paid under clauses 4 and 5 of the deed of the 14th November, 1938, were rightly disallowed as being expenditure of a capital nature and so number allowable under section 10 2   xv  of the Indian Income-tax Act .

facts.text: High Court answered the question in affirmative: payments are capital expenditure, not allowable.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court answered the question in the affirmative and hence this appeal.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal heard on 11 November 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Porus A. Mehta for the respondent. 1954. November, 11. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by, BHAGWATI J.-This appeal from the judgment And order of the High Court of Judicature at Calcutta with leave under section 66-A  2  of the Indian Income-tax Act raises an interesting question as to the line of demarcation between capital expenditure and revenue expenditure.

facts.text: Protection fee under clause 4: Rs. 5,000 annually starting November 15, 1938, for Durgasil area.

anchor.surface_text: Clauses 4 and 5 of the deed of lease may be here set out - The lessee shall pay to the lessor Rs. 5,000  Rupees five thousand  only annually during the period of the lease on November 15th starting from November 15th, 1938, as a protection fee. In companysideration of that protection fee the lessor undertakes number to allow any person or companypany any lease permit or prospecting licence for limestone in the group of quarries as described in Schedule 2- and delineated in the plan thereto annexed and therein companyoured blue called the Durgasil area without a companydition in such lease permit or prospecting licence that numberlimestone ,shall be used for the manufacture of cement.

facts.text: Protection fee under clause 5: Rs. 35,000 annually for 5 years from 15th November 1940, with abatement if limestone exceeds 22,00,000 maunds.

anchor.surface_text: Besides the above protection fee the lessee shall pay to the lessor annually the sum of Rs. 35,000  Rupees thirty five thousand  only for five years starting from the 15th day of November, 1940, as a further protection fee so long as the total amount of limestone quarried by the lessee in a year does number exceed 22,00,000 maunds per year whether quarried in the area of this lease or elsewhere or obtained by purchase from other quarries in the Khasi and Jaintia Hills by the lessees.

facts.text: Lessor could terminate clause 5 after 5 years with 6 months notice.

anchor.surface_text: The lessor will be empowered to terminate this agreement for the payment of a protection fee at any time after it has run for 5 years by giving six month, numberice in writing by registered letter addressed to 11, Clive Street, Calcutta but the lessee will number be entitled to terminate this agreement during the currency of the lease except with the companysent of the lessor.

facts.text: Supreme Court held payments under clauses 4 and 5 are capital expenditure, not deductible under section 10(2)(xv).

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of the opinion that the companyclusion reached by the Income-tax authorities as well as the High Court in regard to the nature of the payments was companyrect and the sums of Rs. 40,000 paid by the companypany to the lessors during the accounting years 1944-45 and 1945-46 were number allowable deductions under section 10 2   xv  of the Act.

facts.text: Company's business: manufacture of cement using limestone from quarries in Khasi and Jaintia Hills District.

anchor.surface_text: the appellant companypany acquired from the Government of Assam a lease of certain limestone quarries, known as the Komorrah quarries situated in the Khasi and Jaintia Hills District for the purpose of carrying on the manufacture of cement.

facts.text: Lessee has factory in Sylhet district.

anchor.surface_text: If, however, in any year the total amount of limestone companyverted into cement at the lessees Sylhet,Factory exceed 22,00,000 maunds the lessee will be entitled to an abatement at the rate of Rs. 20 for every 1,000 maunds quarried in excess of 22,00,000 maunds
with leave under section 66-A  2  of the Indian Income-tax Act raises an interesting question as to the line of demarcation between capital expenditure and revenue expenditure.

anchor.surface_text: You do not use it for the purpose of your concern, which means, for the purpose of carrying on your concern, but you use it to acquire the concern. The expenditure in the acquisition of the concern would be capital expenditure the expenditure in carrying on the concern would be revenue expenditure.

issues.text: This appeal from the judgment And order of the High Court of Judicature at Calcutta with leave under section 66-A 2 of the Indian Income-tax Act raises an interesting question as to the line of demarcation between capital expenditure and revenue expenditure.

anchor.surface_text: with leave under section 66-A  2  of the Indian Income-tax Act raises an interesting question as to the line of demarcation between capital expenditure and revenue expenditure. On the 14th November, 1938, the appellant company acquired

issues.text: Whether, in the circumstances of the case, the two sums of Rs. 5,000 and Rs. 35,000 paid under clauses 4 and 5 of the deed of the 14th November, 1938, were rightly disallowed as being expenditure of a capital nature and so not allowable under section 10 2   xv  of the Indian Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: Whether, in the circumstances of the case, the two sums of Rs. 5,000 and Rs. 35,000 paid under clauses 4 and 5 of the deed of the 14th November, 1938, were rightly disallowed as being expenditure of a capital nature and so not allowable under section 10 2   xv  of the Indian Income-tax Act . The High Court answered the question in the affirmative and hence this appeal.

arguments.claim: Expenditure made once and for all with a view to bringing into existence an asset or advantage for the enduring benefit of a trade is capital expenditure

arguments.claim: Rs. 5,000 annual payment under clause 4 acquires enduring benefit (protection in Durgasil area for whole lease), hence capital not deductible under section 10(2)(xv)

anchor.surface_text: Under clause 4 of the deed the lessors undertook not to grant any lease, permit or prospecting license regarding limestone to any other party in respect of the group of quarries called the Durgasil area without a condition therein that no limestone shall be used for the manufacture of cement.

arguments.claim: Rs. 35,000 payment under clause 5 acquires enduring advantage (protection in whole district for lease period), hence capital not deductible under section 10(2)(xv)

anchor.surface_text: The further protection fee which was paid by the company to the lessor under clause 5 of the deed was also of a similar nature. It was no doubt spread over a period of 5 years, but the advantage which the company got as a result of the payment was to enure for its benefit

arguments.claim: Classification of expenditure as capital or revenue is a question of fact for income-tax authorities; courts do not interfere if arrived at on proper application of principles

anchor.surface_text: The question has all along been considered to be a question of fact to be determined by the Income-tax authorities on an application of the broad principles laid down above and the courts of law would not ordinarily interfere with such findings of fact

arguments.claim: Expenditure is capital if made for acquiring or bringing into existence an asset or advantage for enduring benefit of business, irrespective of whether payment once-and-for-all or periodic, or source (capital or income)

anchor.surface_text: Outlay is deemed to be capital when it is made for the initiation of a business, for extension of a business, or for a substantial replacement of equipment vide Lord Sands in Commissioners of Inland Revenue v. Granite City Steamship Company

arguments.claim: Recurring or instalment payments can be capital if for procuring enduring benefit, not determined by form of payment

anchor.surface_text: The expression once and for all used by Lord Dunedin has created some difficulty and it has been contended that where the payment is not in a lump sum but in instalments it cannot satisfy the test. Whether a payment be in a lump sum or by instalments, what has got to be looked to is the character of the payment.

holdings.text: The expenditure made by the company in acquiring this advantage which was certainly an enduring advantage was thus of the nature of capital expenditure and was not an allowable deduction under section 10(2)(xv) of the Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: The expenditure made by the companypany in acquiring this advantage which was certainly an enduring advantage was thus of the nature of capital expenditure and was number an allowable deduction under section 10 2  xv  of the Income-tax Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Payment under clause 4 secures enduring benefit of protection in Durgasil area for whole lease period, enhancing capital asset value; recurring nature immaterial.

holdings.text: This again was the acquisition of an asset or advantage of an enduring nature for the whole of the business and was of the nature of capital expenditure and thus was not an allowable deduction under section 10(2)(xv) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The further protection fee which was paid by the companypany to the lessor under clause 5 of the deed was also of a similar nature. It was numberdoubt spread over a period of 5 years, but the advantage which the companypany got as a result of the payment was to enure for its benefit

holdings.reasoning_summary: Payment under clause 5 secures enduring advantage of district-wide protection for lease duration despite 5-year payment period, appreciating capital asset; not operational expense.

holdings.text: We are therefore of the opinion that the conclusion reached by the Income-tax authorities as well as the High Court in regard to the nature of the payments was correct and the sums of Rs. 40,000 paid by the company to the lessors during the accounting years 1944-45 and 1945-46 were not allowable deductions under section 10(2)(xv) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of the opinion that the companyclusion reached by the Income-tax authorities as well as the High Court in regard to the nature of the payments was companyrect and the sums of Rs. 40,000 paid by the companypany to the lessors during the accounting years 1944-45 and 1945-46 were number allowable deductions under section 10 2   xv  of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Lower authorities correctly classified payments under clauses 4 and 5 as capital using enduring benefit test and related principles applied to lease facts.

holdings.text: Expenditure is capital if made for acquiring or bringing into existence an asset or advantage for the enduring benefit of the business irrespective of whether payment is once and for all or periodic.

anchor.surface_text: Outlay is deemed to be capital when it is made for the initiation of a business, for extension of a business, or for a substantial replacement of equipment vide Lord Sands in Commissioners of Inland Revenue v. Granite City Steamship Company

holdings.reasoning_summary: Synthesis of precedents (Atherton, Benarsidas) confirms enduring benefit determines capital nature over form of payment or source.
